meta.name: generator
meta.content: HTML Tidy for Windows (vers 14 February 2006), see www.w3.org

div.p: Plugin Version @PLUGIN_VERSION@
Revised on June 17, 2015

WebLogic is a server software application that runs on a
middle tier, between back-end databases and related
applications and browser-based thin clients. The main
features of WebLogic server include connectors that make it
possible for any legacy application on any client to
interoperate with server applications, Enterprise JavaBean
(EJB) components, resource pooling, and connection sharing
that make applications very scalable. An administration
console with a user interface makes management tasks more
efficient and features such as Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)
support for the encryption of data transmissions, as well
as authentication and authorization mechanisms, make
applications and secure.

For more information about WebLogic, go to
WebLogic home page.

Use this plugin to interact with the Oracle
WebLogic server for application and server management,
interacting or editing existing applications, and deploying new applications.
You can start and stop both the Managed Servers and the Admin Server
using this integration. You can use Jython scripting to create script files
or to enter a new embedded file.
This plugin was developed and tested against WebLogic version 10.3.
IMPORTANT: In the ElectricFlow UI, go to the Home page, open the Main Menu, and click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.

Plugin configurations are sets of parameters that apply across some or all of the plugin procedures. They reduce repetition of common values, create predefined sets of parameters for end users, and store credentials securely. Each configuration has a unique name that is automatically entered in designated parameters in the procedures.

ol.li: In the Main Menu, click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Find the EC-WebLogic row.
Click Configure to open the WebLogic Configurations page.
Click Create Configuration.

To create a WebLogic configuration, enter the following information and click OK.
Remember that you may need to create additional configurations later.

tr.td: The URL of the WebLogic server that includes the protocol, server, and port.

ul.li: User Name: Enter the name of the WebLogic user.
Password: Enter the password for the WebLogic user name.
Retype Password: Re-enter the password for the WebLogic user name.

ol.p:
Note: In the URL, the protocol is "t3." The
RMI communications in WebLogic Server use
the "t3" protocol to transport data between WebLogic
Server and other Java programs, including clients and
other WebLogic Server instances. A server instance
keeps track of each Java Virtual Machine (JVM) with
which it connects, and creates a single "t3" connection
to carry all traffic for a JVM. This proctocol is used
in most of the procedures of the WebLogic Plugin.

div.p: The WebLogic Configurations page now shows the new configuration.
You can also manage your WebLogic configurations in this page. Click Edit to modify an existing configuration or Delete to remove an existing configuration.
IMPORTANT: For all parameter descriptions in this document, required parameters are shown in bold italics.

This procedure deploys or redeploys an application or module using
the weblogic.Deployer Java class.

ol.li: In the Main Menu, click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Go to the DeployApp procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter
Description
Java Absolute Path
Absolute path of java. For example: i.e: "java", "java.exe", or "/path/to/java".
Java Parameters
Java parameters to pass, such as -verbose.
Application Name
Deployment name to assign to a newly deployed application or standalone module.
Application Path
Absolute path of the application to deploy, such as "/path/to/webapp.war" or "c:/mydir/webapp.war".
Configuration Name
Name of the configuration to use when the URL and credentials for the Admin Server are retrieved.
Targets
Targets on which to deploy the application or module in a comma-separated list
of the target servers, clusters, or virtual hosts.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered in the weblogic.Deployer tool.
setDomainEnv Script Absolute Path
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv script, including filename and extension.
For example, "/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or "setDomainEnv.cmd".
weblogic jar Absolute Path
Absolute path of the weblogic.jar file that is required
to run the Deploy function. In a
Windows environment, if the jar file is already
added to the environment classpath variable,
it is not necesary to include it. In a
Linux environment, you must include the
path, such as "/path/to/weblogic.jar" or
"/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: After the job runs, you can view the results on the Job Details page in ElectricFlow. The application was deployed successfully.
In the DeployApp step, click the Log button to see the diagnostic information: .

This procedure stops the deployment unit and removes staged files
from target servers.

ol.li: In the Main Menu, click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Go to the UndeployApp procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter
Description
Java Absolute Path
Absolute path to Java, such as "java",
"java.exe", or "/path/to/java".
Java Parameters
Java parameters to pass, such as "-verbose".
Application Name
Name of the application to undeploy, such as "webapp".
Enable Graceful Mode
Enables stopping the application in Graceful Mode after the existing HTTP clients
have completed their work.
Configuration Name
Name of the configuration to be used when the Admin Server URL and credentials
are retrieved.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered in the weblogic.Deployer tool.
setDomainEnv Script Absolute Path
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv
script, including filename and extension.
For example, "/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or
"setDomainEnv.cmd".
weblogic jar Absolute Path
Absolute path of the weblogic.jar file that is
required to run the Undeploy function. In a
Windows environment, if the jar file is already
added to the environment classpath variable,
it is not necesary to include it. In a
Linux environment, you must include the
path, such as "/path/to/weblogic.jar" or
"/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: After the job runs, you can view the results on the Job Details page in ElectricFlow. The application was undeployed successfully.
In the UndeployApp step, click the Log button to see the diagnostic information: .
This procedures starts an application.

ol.li: In the Main Menu, click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Go to the StartApp procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter
Description
Java Absolute Path
Absolute path to Java, such as "java",
"java.exe", or "/path/to/java".
Java Parameters
Java parameters to pass, such as "-verbose".
Application Name
Name of the application to start, such as "webapp".
Configuration Name
Name of the configuration to be used
for retrieving Admin Server URL and
credentials.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered in the
weblogic.Deployer tool.
setDomainEnv Script Absolute Path
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv
script, including filename and extension, such as
"/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or "setDomainEnv.cmd".
weblogic jar Absolute Path
Absolute path of the weblogic.jar file that is
needed to run the start application
operation. In a Windows environment, if the
jar file has already added been to the environment
classpath variable, it is not necesary to
include it. In a Linux environment you must
include the path, such as or
"/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: After the job runs, you can view the results on the Job Details page in ElectricFlow. The application was undeployed successfully.
In the StartApp step, click the Log button to see the diagnostic information: .
This procedure stops an application.

ol.li: In the Main Menu, click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Go to the StopApp procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter
Description
Java Absolute
Path
Absolute path of java, such as "java",
"java.exe", or "/path/to/java".
Java Parameters
Java parameters to pass, such as "-verbose".
Application Name
Name of the application to stop, such as "webapp".
Enable Graceful Mode
Enables stopping the application in
Graceful Mode after existing HTTP clients
have completed their work.
Configuration Name
Name of the configuration to use when
the Admin Server URL and
credentials are retrieved.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered in the
weblogic.Deployer tool.
setDomainEnv Script Absolute Path
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv
script, including filename and extension, such as
"/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or
"setDomainEnv.cmd".
weblogic jar Absolute Path
Absolute path of the weblogic.jar file that is
required to run the stop application
operation. In a Windows environment, if the
jar file has already been added to the environment
classpath variable, it is not necesary to
include it. In a Linux environment you must
include the path, such as
"/path/to/weblogic.jar" or
"/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: After the job runs, you can view the results on the Job Details page in ElectricFlow. The application was undeployed successfully.
In the UndeployApp step, click the Log button to see the diagnostic information: .

This procedure runs weblogic.Deployer tool in a free mode.
The weblogic.Deployer tool is a Java-based deployment tool that
provides a command-line interface to the WebLogic
Server deployment API.

ol.li: In the Main Menu, click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Go to the RunDeployer procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter
Description
Command to Use
The weblogic.Deployer command to use, such sa "-deploy", "-undeploy", "-stop" or "-listapps".
Java Parameters
Java parameters to pass, such as "-verbose".
Configuration Name
Name of the configuration to use when the Admin Server URL and credentials are retrieved.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered in the
weblogic.Deployer tool.
Java Absolute Path
Absolute path of java, such as "java", "java.exe" or "/path/to/java".
Application Name
Name of the application to stop, such as "webapp".
setDomainEnv Script Absolute Path
Absolute path of the setDomainEnv
script, including filename and extension, such as
"/path/to/setDomainEnv.sh" or
"setDomainEnv.cmd".
weblogic jar Absolute Path
Absolute path of the weblogic.jar file that is
required to run the stop application
operation. In a Windows environment, if the
jar file has already been added to the environment
classpath variable, it is not necesary to
include it. In a Linux environment you must
include the path, such as
"/path/to/weblogic.jar" or
"/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: After the job runs, you can view the results on the Job Details page in ElectricFlow. The application was undeployed successfully.
In the RunDeployer step, click the Log button to see the diagnostic information: .

This procedure runs Jython scripts using weblogic.WLST. The
WebLogic Scripting Tool (WLST) is a command-line
scripting interface that system administrators and
operators use to monitor and manage WebLogic Server
instances and domains. The WLST scripting environment
is based on the Java scripting interpreter, Jython. In
addition to WebLogic scripting functions, you can use
common features of interpreted languages, including
local variables, conditional variables, and flow
control statements.

ol.li: In the Main Menu, click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Go to the RunDeployer procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter
Description
WLST Absolute Path
Absolute path to WLST, such as
"/path/to/wlst.cmd" or "wlst.sh".
Script File Absolute Path
Absolute path of a Jython script
containing the desired job. The path is
used only if "Supplied File" is selected in
the "Script File Source" parameter, such as
"/path/to/scriptfile.jython".
Script File
Source
Indicates the source of the script file
to execute: an existing file in the
path defined in the "Script File" parameter
or a new one using the code specified in
"Script File" parameter.
Script File
Content of the script file to run if the
"New Script File" option is chosen in the
"Script File Source" parameter.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to enter in
weblogic.WLST.
weblogic jar Absolute Path
Absolute path of the weblogic.jar file that are
required to run Jython scripts using
weblogic.WLST. In a Windows environment, if
the jar file is already added to the environment
classpath variable, then is not necesary to
include it. In a Linux environment you must
include the path, such as
"/path/to/weblogic.jar" or
"/root/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/lib/weblogic.jar".

div.p: To see a complete example, see the Examples and Use Cases section.
This procedure starts the WebLogic Admin Server.

ol.li: In the Main Menu, click Admin > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Go to the StartAdminServer procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter
Description
Script Location
Absolute path of the startWeblogic
script, including filename and extension.
For example, "/path/to/startWeblogic.cmd".
Admin Server Instance
Name
Instance name of the Admin Server to
start, such as "AdminServer".
Config Name
Configuration name from which the Admin
URL and credentials will be read.
WLST Absolute
Path
Absolute path to WLST, such as
"/path/to/wlst.cmd" or "wlst.sh".
Maximum Elapsed Time
Defines the maximum time in seconds
that the job will try to check into the
server. Note that the step has a "Time
Limit" property, so if this property is set
to less than the parameter it will abort
the step early. Blank implies no wait time
(URL only checked one time).

div.p: After the job runs, you can view the results on the Job Details page in ElectricFlow. The application was undeployed successfully.
In the StartAdminServer step, click the Log button to see the diagnostic information: .

This procedure starts a WebLogic Managed Server. A WebLogic Server
administration domain is a logically related group of
WebLogic Server resources. Usually, you configure a
domain to include additional WebLogic Server instances
called Managed Servers. You deploy Web applications,
EJBs, and other resources onto the Managed Servers and
use the Administration Server for configuration and
management purposes only. Note that the Node Manager
must be running before run this procedure.

In order to start the managed server, a file called
"boot.properties" must be created in the path
"$DOMAIN_DIR$/servers/myserver/security", and this file
must have the credentials needed to start the server.
i.e:
username=weblogic
password=w3blogic

tr.td:
Absolute path of the start server
script, including filename and extension.
i.e: "/path/to/startManagedServer.cmd".

Instance name of the Managed Server to
start.

Configuration name from which the
Managed Server URL and the credentials from
the Admin Server will be read.

URL from the Admin Server (including
protocol and port).

Absolute path to WLST. i.e:
"/path/to/wlst.cmd" or "wlst.sh".

Defines the maximum time in seconds
that the job will try to check into the
server. Note that the step has a "Time
Limit" property, so if this property is set
to less than the parameter it will abort
the step early. Blank implies no wait time
(URL only checked one time).

Defines the maximum time in seconds

To stop the admin server, select the following

Note: in the URL the protocol is "http", this
is because for this procedure, the ElectricFlow
use an internal method to test the status of the URL
pages with the original "http" protocol used in the web
browsers.

Starts the WebLogic Node Manager. Node Manager is a
WebLogic Server utility that enables you to start, shut
down, and restart Administration Server and Managed
Server instances from a remote location. Although Node
Manager is optional, it is recommended if your WebLogic
Server environment hosts applications with high
availability requirements.

tr.td:
Absolute path of the startNodeManager
script, including filename and extension.
i.e:
'/Oracle/Middleware/wlserver_10.3/server/bin/startNodeManager.cmd'.

Defines the time in seconds that the
job wait to test the status of the node
manager. Note that the step has a "Time
Limit" property, so if this property is set
to less than the parameter it will abort
the step early. Blank implies no wait time
(URL only checked one time).

div.p:
To start the node manager, select the following
highlighted
step:

Then, enter the following
parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the
following job detail, note the output indicating the
node manager was started
successfully:

In the CheckNodeManagerStatus step, click the
Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is
similar to the following diagnostic
report:
Stops the WebLogic Node Manager.

tr.td:
Configuration name from which the
credentials will be read.

Host name of Node Manager. This
argument defaults to localhost.

Port number of Node Manager. This
argument defaults to a value that is based
on the Node Manager server type, for plain
type, defaults to 5556. For rsh type,
defaults to 514. For ssh type, defaults to
22. For ssl type, defaults to 5556.

Name of the domain that you want to
manage. This argument defaults to
mydomain.

Path of the domain directory to which
you want to save the Node Manager secret
file (nm_password.properties) and
SerializedSystemIni.dat file. This argument
defaults to the directory in which WLST was
started.

Absolute path to WLST. i.e:
'/path/to/wlst.cmd' or 'wlst.sh'.

Type of the Node Manager server. This
argument defaults to ssl.

Defines the time in seconds that the
job wait to test the status of the node
manager. Note that the step has a "Time
Limit" property, so if this property is set
to less than the parameter it will abort
the step early. Blank implies no wait time
(URL only checked one time).

div.p:
To stop the node manager, select the following
highlighted
step:

Then, enter the following
parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the
following job detail, note the output indicating the
node manager was stopped
successfully:

In the CheckNodeManagerStatus step, click the
Log icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is
similar to the following diagnostic
report:
Creates a datasource in WebLogic.

tr.td: Configuration name from which the Admin URL and credentials will be read.
Absolute path to WLST. i.e: '/path/to/wlst.cmd' or 'wlst.sh'.
A unique name that identifies this Datasource in the WebLogic domain.
The database used by the Datasource.
Instance name of the Server to include the Datasource. i.e: 'AdminServer'.

The JNDI path to where this Datasource is bound. By default, the JNDI name is the name of the Datasource. Applications that look up the JNDI path will get a "javax.sql.Datasource" instance that corresponds to this Datasource.

The full package name of JDBC driver class used to create the physical database connections in the connection pool. (Note that this driver class must be in the classpath of any server to which it is deployed).
The URL of the database to connect to. The format of the URL varies by JDBC driver. The URL is passed to the JDBC driver to create the physical database connections.
The user to connect to the database.

The password attribute passed to the JDBC driver when creating physical database connections. The value is stored in an encrypted form in the descriptor file and when displayed on the Administration Console.

div.p:
To create a Datasource, select the following
highlighted
step:

Then, enter the following
parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the
following job detail, note the output indicating the
datasource was creted
successfully:

In the CreateDatasource step, click the Log icon to
see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the
following diagnostic
report:
Deletes a WebLogic Datasource.

tr.td: Configuration name from which the Admin URL and credentials will be read.
Absolute path to WLST. i.e: '/path/to/wlst.cmd' or 'wlst.sh'.
The unique name that identifies this Datasource in the WebLogic domain to delete it.

div.p:
To delete a Datasource, select the following
highlighted
step:

Then, enter the following
parameters:

When the job is executed, you should see the
following job detail, note the output indicating the
datasource was deleted
successfully:

In the DeleteDatasource step, click the Log icon to
see the diagnostic info. The output is similar to the
following diagnostic
report:
Suspends a WebLogic server.

tr.td: Configuration name from which the Admin URL and credentials will be read.
Absolute path to WLST. i.e: '/path/to/wlst.cmd' or 'wlst.sh'.
Name of the server to suspend.

Boolean value specifying whether WLST should drop all HTTP sessions immediately or wait for HTTP sessions to complete or time out while suspending. This argument defaults to false, indicating that HTTP sessions must complete or time out.
Time (in seconds) the WLST waits for the server to complete in-process work before suspending the server. This argument defaults to 0 seconds, indicating that there is no timeout.

Boolean value specifying whether WLST should suspend the server without waiting for active sessions to complete. This argument defaults to false, indicating that all active sessions must complete before suspending the server.

Boolean value specifying whether WLST blocks user interaction until the server is started. This argument defaults to false, indicating that user interaction is not blocked. In this case, WLST returns control to the user after issuing the command and assigns the task MBean associated with the current task to a variable that you can use to check its status. If you are importing WLST as a Jython module, as described in Importing WLST as a Jython Module, block is always set to true.

div.p:
To suspend a server, select the following
highlighted
step:

Then, enter the following
parameters:

server was suspended

following diagnostic
report:
Resumes a WebLogic server.

tr.td: Configuration name from which the Admin URL and credentials will be read.
Absolute path to WLST. i.e: '/path/to/wlst.cmd' or 'wlst.sh'.
Name of the server to resume.

Boolean value specifying whether WLST blocks user interaction until the server is started. This argument defaults to false, indicating that user interaction is not blocked. In this case, WLST returns control to the user after issuing the command and assigns the task MBean associated with the current task to a variable that you can use to check its status. If you are importing WLST as a Jython module, as described in Importing WLST as a Jython Module, block is always set to true.

World!' in the output using the Supplied File option
with an existing scrit file in a path, and using the New

step:

File:

execution, this applies for both Script File Source

used in the Supplied File
option:

ul.li: Fixed the manifest file.
Fixed typos in references to the createDataSource and deleteDataSource files in the manifest.pl so that the files are included correctly in the plugin jar.
Fixed errors in the createDataSource procedure.
Added four procedures to create datasources, delete datasources, suspend a server, and resume a server.
Fixed minor bugs.
Procedure names were changed in the step picker section.

Added a parameter in the start and stop server
procedures to determine the maximum time in seconds to
test the status of the server.
Created two procedures to start and stop the Node Manager.
Changes to Help files.
Upgrade to use the new Parameter Form XML.
Added a link directly to the new Help file.
New Help Page Format.
Add new Parameter Panels for each procedure.

Add the weblogic jar Absolute Path parameter to
the DeployApp, UndeployApp, StartApp, StopApp,
RunDeployer and RunWLST procedures. It is required to a Linux
environment to load WebLogic libreries.

Add the Admin Server URL parameter to the
StartManagedServer procedure.
Fixed minor issues.
Fix issue affecting workspace setting.
Add the CheckPageStatus procedure.

Modify the CheckServerProcedure procedure. CURL
is not needed and parameters were changed.
Fix minor bugs.
Remove the CURL dependency.
Add new postp matchers.
Fixed minor bug on Configuration List page.

Procedures that have only one step are executed
using Perl directly.

Credentials in the StartManagedServer procedure
must be stored in a boot.properties file.
